entries.content: Get the prospect to discover they have a problem; don't tell them directly to avoid upsetting them.
People buy emotionally; facts alone don't sell. Connect facts and figures to how they negatively impact the prospect.
Avoid only asking factual 'who, what, when, where, why, how' questions; they gather facts but don't drive emotional realization.
Use presumptive questions: ask a question assuming they know the answer or have already considered something.
entries.notes: A strategy to uncover reasons for inaction or potential barriers.

entries.content: Example presumptive question: 'When you were offered the opportunity to automate this... why did you say no to it?'
entries.notes: Forces the prospect to explain why they haven't solved the problem.

entries.content: Example presumptive question: 'When you turn to your sales guys and ask them why aren't you hitting target, what did they say?'
entries.notes: Uncovers their perspective on internal issues or excuses.

entries.content: Presumptive questions are a good strategy to develop; they force the prospect to justify their current state or lack of action.
